snippet: Stock volumes have dwindled since the financial crisis, and some fear that investors wary of stocks may have trouble generating respectable returns from the ultralow interest rates of the bond market.
abstract: Volume of stock trading in the United States has failed to recover since the 2008 financial crisis and has continued to fall; decline stands in marked contrast to 1987 and 2001, when Americans regained their taste for stock trading within two years of economic shocks. Chart, Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Even though American stocks have doubled in price in the last three years, investors and traders large and small keep giving the market the cold shoulder. Trading in the United States stock market has not only failed to recover since the 2008 financial crisis, it has continued to fall. In April, the average daily trades in American stocks on all exchanges stood at nearly half of its peak in 2008: 6.5 billion compared with 12.1 billion, according to Credit Suisse Trading Strategy.

headline.main: Stock Trading Is Still Falling After '08 Crisis
